para.text: HUF2 - Hydrogeologic-Unit Flow Package

table.style: width:auto; cell-padding:2px; cell-spacing:2px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:1px; border-spacing:2px; cell-border-width:1px; border-color:#000000; border-style:raised-color; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: HUF2
Purpose

The Hydrogeologic-Unit Flow package is used to specify properties controlling flow between cells. It allows you to specify these properties by "hydrogeologic unit". The unit boundaries are not required to correspond to layer boundaries. The properties of individual cells is synthesized from the properties of the hydrogeologic units that intersect the cell.
Documentation

li.link: Anderman, E.R., and Hill, M.C., 2000, MODFLOW-2000, the U.S. Geological Survey Modular Ground-Water Model - Documentation of the Hydrogeologic-Unit Flow (HUF) Package: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 00-342, 89 p.

Anderman, E.R., Kipp, K.L., Hill, M.C., Valstar, Johan, and Neupauer, R.M., 2002, MODFLOW-2000, the U.S. Geological Survey modular ground-water model -- Documentation of the Model-Layer Variable-Direction Horizontal Anisotropy (LVDA) capability of the Hydrogeologic-Unit Flow (HUF) Package: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 02-409, 60 p.

Anderman, E.R., and Hill, M.C., 2003, MODFLOW-2000, the U.S. Geological Survey modular ground-water model -- Three additions to the Hydrogeologic-Unit Flow (HUF) Package: Alternative storage for the uppermost active cells, Flows in hydrogeologic units, and the Hydraulic-coductivity depth-dependence (KDEP) capability: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 03-347, 36 p.

para.text: Related Packages

li.text: The
and the
are two other packages that can be used to specify properties controlling flow between cells.
The
modifies the horizontal conductances between certain, specified pairs of cells.

para.text: Supported in

li.text: MODFLOW-2000
MODFLOW-2005
MODFLOW-LGR
MODFLOW-CFP
MODFLOW-NWT
MODFLOW-OWHM

li.text: The "
" capability is provided in the
input file but is part of the Hydrogeologic Unit Flow package.
The "
" capability is provided in the
input file but is part of the Hydrogeologic Unit Flow package.
The "
" capability (
) is incompatible with the
and with the
Sensitivity (SEN)
process.

li.text: The

link.style: font-family:'Times New Roman'; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:line-through; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

text.style: font-family:'Times New Roman'; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:line-through; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

li.text: package reads values of hydraulic conductivity and specific yield from the

link.style: font-family:'Times New Roman'; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:line-through; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

text.style: font-family:'Times New Roman'; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:line-through; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

li.text: and

link.style: font-family:'Times New Roman'; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:line-through; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

text.style: font-family:'Times New Roman'; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:line-through; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

li.text: packages but not the HUF package. Therefore, the HUF2 package can not be used with the

link.style: font-family:'Times New Roman'; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:line-through; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

text.style: font-family:'Times New Roman'; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:line-through; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

li.text: package.
As of MODFLOW2005 version 1.5, the
package can be used with the HUF2 package.
The
package does not support unsaturated flow when the HUF package is used.
The
SOR
solver
(not included in MODFLOW-2005 and MODFLOW-LGR)
doesn't work well with the wetting capability.
The vertical flow from or to a
is calculated incorrectly when the HUF package is used. This bug is present in MODFLOW-2005 version 1.9.1 and in all earlier versions.
This bug has been fixed in MODFLOW-NWT version 1.7 and MODFLOW-2005 version 1.10.

para.text: Input Instructions
Input for the Hydrogeologic Unit Flow (HUF) Package is read from the file that has type "HUF" in the
file. Free format is used for reading all values.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:2px; cell-spacing:2px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:1px; border-spacing:2px; cell-border-width:1px; border-color:#000000; border-style:raised-color; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: FOR EACH SIMULATION
Data Set 0
[#Text]
Item 0 is optional -- “#” must be in column 1. Item 0 can be repeated multiple times.

table.style: width:auto; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: Text – is a character variable (199 characters) that starts in column 2. Any characters can be included in Text. The “#” character must be in column 1. Text is printed when the file is read.
Data Set 1
IHUFCB HDRY NHUF NPHUF IOHUFHEADS IOHUFFLOWS

table.style: width:auto; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

width:auto; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: IHUFCB – is a flag and a unit number.

li.text: > 0 –the unit number to which cell-by-cell flow terms will be written when "SAVE BUDGET" or a non-zero value for
is specified in
(Harbaugh and others, 2000, p. 55). The terms that are saved are storage, constant-head flow, and flow between adjacent cells.
0 – cell-by-cell flow terms will not be written.
< 0 – cell-by-cell flow for constant-head cells will be written in the listing file when "SAVE BUDGET" or a non-zero value for
is specified in
. Cell-by-cell flow to storage and between adjacent cells will not be written to any file.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: HDRY – is the head that is assigned to cells that are converted to dry during a simulation. Although this value plays no role in the model calculations, it is useful as an indicator when looking at the resulting heads that are output from the model. HDRY is thus similar to
in the Basic Package, which is the value assigned to cells that are no-flow cells at the start of a model simulation.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: NHUF – is the number of hydrogeologic units defined using the HUF package.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: NPHUF – is the number of HUF parameters.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: IOHUFHEADS – is a flag and a unit number.

text.style: font-family:'Times New Roman'; font-size:12pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:line-through; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

li.text: < 0 (MODFLOW-2005 and MODFLOW-LGR only) Interpolated heads will be computed and printed to the listing file for each hydrogeologic unit, using the format defined in the output-control file when "SAVE HEADS" is specified or (equivalently) when nonzero values are specified for IHDDFL and for Hdsv in at least one layer. (If no print format has been defined, printing will be in 10G11.4 format.)
As of MODFLOW-2005 version 1.11, this option had not been implemented.
0 – interpolated heads will not be written.

>0 – Interpolated heads will be computed and saved to unit IOHUFHEADS for each hydrogeologic unit, using the format defined in the output-control file when "SAVE HEADS" is specified or (equivalently) when nonzero values are specified for IHDDFL and for Hdsv in at least one layer. (If no print format has been defined, saving will be in binary format.)

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: IOHUFFLOWS– is a flag and a unit number.

li.text: 0 – Interpolated cell-by-cell flows will not be computed or written anywhere.

> 0 – Interpolated cell-by-cell flows will be computed and saved to unit IOHUFFLOWS for each hydrogeologic unit, in binary format, when "SAVE BUDGET" or (equivalently) a nonzero value for ICBCFL is specified..

para.text: Data Set 2

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: LTHUF – is a flag specifying the layer type. Read one value for each layer; each element holds the code for the respective layer. There is a limit of 200 layers. Use as many records as needed to enter a value for each layer.

li.text: 0 – indicates a confined layer.
not 0 – indicates a convertible layer.

para.text: Data Set 3

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: LAYWT – is a flag that indicates if wetting is active. Read one value per layer.

li.text: 0 – indicates wetting is inactive.
1 – indicates wetting is active.

para.text: Data Set 4
WETFCT IWETIT IHDWET
Include Item 4 only if LAYWT indicates at least one wettable layer.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: WETFCT – is a factor that is included in the calculation of the head that is initially established at a cell when the cell is converted from dry to wet. (See

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: IWETIT – is the iteration interval for attempting to wet cells. Wetting is attempted every IWETIT iterations. If using the preconditioned conjugate gradient (PCG) solver (Hill, 1990), this applies to outer iterations, not inner iterations. If IWETIT is less than or equal to 0, it is changed to 1.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: IHDWET – is a flag that determines which equation is used to define the initial head at cells that become wet:

li.text: If IHDWET = 0, equation 3a from McDonald and others (1992) is used:

para.text: h = BOT + WETFCT (hn - BOT)

li.text: If IHDWET is not 0, equation 3b from McDonald and others (1992) is used:

para.text: h = BOT + WETFCT (WETDRY)
Data Set 5
WETDRY(NCOL,NROW) -
Repeat Item 5 for each layer for which LAYWET is not 0.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: WETDRY – is a combination of the wetting threshold and a flag to indicate which neighboring cells can cause a cell to become wet. If WETDRY < 0, only the cell below a dry cell can cause the cell to become wet. If WETDRY > 0, the cell below a dry cell and the four horizontally adjacent cells can cause a cell to become wet. If WETDRY is 0, the cell cannot be wetted. The absolute value of WETDRY is the wetting threshold. When the sum of BOT and the absolute value of WETDRY at a dry cell is equaled or exceeded by the head at an adjacent cell, the cell is wetted. Read only if
is not 0 and
is not 0.
The
package requires that WETDRY be set to 0 in Lakes.
Repeat Items 6-8 for each hydrogeologic unit to be defined (that is,
times).
Data Set 6

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: HGUNAM – is the name of the hydrogeologic unit. This name can consist of up to 10 characters and is not case sensitive.
Data Set 7
TOP(NCOL,NROW) Arrays are read by the array-reading utility module -

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: TOP – is the elevation of the top of the hydrogeologic unit.
Data Set 8
THCK(NCOL,NROW) Arrays are read by the array-reading utility module -

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: THCK – is the thickness of the hydrogeologic unit.
Data Set 9
HGUNAM HGUHANI HGUVANI
Repeat Item 9 for each hydrogeologic unit.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: If HGUNAM is set to “ALL”, HGUHANI and HGUVANI are set for all hydrogeologic units and only one Item 9 is necessary. Otherwise, HGUNAM must correspond to one of the names defined in Item 6, and there must be NHUF repetitions of Item 9. The repetitions can be in any order.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: HGUHANI – is a flag and a horizontal anisotropy value for a hydrogeologic unit. Horizontal anisotropy is the ratio of hydraulic conductivity along columns to hydraulic conductivity along rows. Read one value for each hydrogeologic unit unless HGUNAM is set to ALL.

li.text: 0 – indicates that horizontal anisotropy will be defined using a HANI parameter.
>0 – HGUHANI is the horizontal anisotropy of the entire hydrogeologic unit.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: HGUVANI – is a flag that indicates whether array VK is vertical hydraulic conductivity or the ratio of horizontal to vertical hydraulic conductivity. Read only one value for each hydrogeologic unit unless HGUNAM is set to ALL.

li.text: 0 – indicates VK is hydraulic conductivity (VK parameter must be used).

>0 – indicates VK is the ratio of horizontal to vertical hydraulic conductivity and HGUVANI is the vertical anisotropy of the entire hydrogeologic unit. Value is ignored if a VANI parameter is defined for the corresponding hydrogeologic unit.

para.text: Repeat Items 10-11 for each parameter to be defined (that is,
times).
Data Set 10
PARNAM PARTYP Parval NCLU

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: PARNAM – is the name of a parameter to be defined. This name can consist of up to 10 characters and is not case sensitive. All parameter names must be unique.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: PARTYP – is the type of parameter to be defined. For the HUF Package, the allowed parameter types are:

li.text: HK – defines variable HK, horizontal hydraulic conductivity.
HANI – defines variable HANI, horizontal anisotropy. When using the
capability, HANI values need to be less than or equal to 1.
(Horizontal anisotropy is the hydraulic conductivity in the Y or column direction divided by the hydraulic conductivity in the X or row direction.)
VK – defines variable VK, vertical hydraulic conductivity, for units for which
is set to zero.
VANI – defines variable VANI, vertical anisotropy, for units for which

is set greater than zero. If the Hydraulic-Conductivity Depth-Dependence Capability is used, the vertical hydraulic conductivity changes according to the changes in the horizontal hydraulic conductivity.
(Vertical anisotropy is the ratio of hydraulic conductivity in the X or row direction to the hydraulic conductivity in the Z or layer direction.)
SS – defines variable Ss, the specific storage.
SY – defines variable Sy, the specific yield.

SYTP – when all model layers are confined, defines the storage coefficient for the top active cell at each row, column location. The value specified is not multiplied by model layer thickness. When SYTP is specified as the parameter type,
of item 11 needs to be set to SYTP.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: NCLU – is the number of clusters required to define the parameter. Each Item-11 record is a cluster (variables HGUNAM, Mltarr, Zonarr, and IZ).
Data Set 11
HGUNAM Mltarr Zonarr IZ
Each Item 11 record is called a parameter cluster. Repeat Item 11 NCLU times.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: HGUNAM – is the hydrogeologic unit to which the parameter applies. When
= SYTP, HGUNAM must be set to SYTP.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: Mltarr – is the name of the multiplier array to be used to define array values that are associated with a parameter. The name “NONE” means that there is no multiplier array, and the array values will be set equal to

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: Zonarr – is the name of the zone array to be used to define array elements that are associated with a parameter. The name “ALL” means that there is no zone array and that all elements in the hydrogeologic unit are part of the parameter.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: IZ – is up to 10 zone numbers (separated by spaces) that define the array elements that are associated with a parameter. The first zero or non-numeric value terminates the list. These values are not used if Zonarr is specified as “ALL”.
Data Set 12
PRINT
HGUNAM PRINTCODE PRINTFLAGS
Item 12 is optional and is included only for hydrogeologic units for which printing is desired. Item 12 must start with the word PRINT.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: If HGUNAM is set to ALL, PRINTCODE and PRINTFLAGS are set for all hydrogeologic units, and only one Item 12 is necessary. Otherwise, HGUNAM must correspond to one of the names defined in Item 6.

table.style: width:100%; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: PRINTCODE – determines the format for printing the values of the hydraulic-property arrays for the hydrogeologic unit as defined by parameters. The print codes are the same as those used in an
(Harbaugh and others, 2000, p. 87).
If PRINTCODE is set to zero, the array will not be printed.

table.style: width:auto; cell-padding:0px; cell-spacing:0px; page-break-inside:auto; border-width:0px; border-spacing:0px; cell-border-width:0px; border-style:none; background-color:none; head-row-background-color:none; alt-row-background-color:none;

para.text: PRINTFLAGS – determines the hydraulic-property arrays to be printed and must be set to “ALL” or any of the following: “HK”, “HANI”, “VK”, “SS”, or “SY”. Arrays will be printed only for those properties that are listed. When VK is specified, the property printed depends on the setting of
All the PRINTFLAGS for a hydrogeologic unit must be specified on the same line.
